name: mephobarbital
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1408

name: mephobarbital
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1408
Reason: The target compound mephobarbital consists of a barbiturate core with two keto groups and an attached phenyl group. The basic unit for comparison is urea, which has a melting point of 133°C. The barbiturate core introduces additional rigidity and more hydrogen bonding opportunities. Each keto group contributes to an increase in melting point due to the potential for hydrogen bonding and dipolar interactions, estimated at +20°C per keto group. The phenyl group typically increases melting point due to added pi-pi stacking interactions and increased molecular weight, estimated at +25°C. The two ethyl groups add to the molecular weight and also introduce van der Waals interactions, however, due to steric hinderance and flexibility they have a lesser effect on the melting point. We estimate this at +5°C per ethyl group. Given these considerations: urea basic unit (+133°C), addition of barbiturate core (unknown value), two keto groups (+40°C), one phenyl group (+25°C), and two ethyl groups (+10°C)

name: mephobarbital
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1408
Reason: The target compound mephobarbital consists of a barbiturate core which increases melting points due to the rigid structure and hydrogen bonding availability. A basic barbiturate molecule has a melting point of around 190°C. Each keto group can increase the melting point due to hydrogen bonding and dipolar interactions, estimated at +5°C per keto group, considering that the groups are already part of the barbiturate core and their effects are somewhat inherent to the basic barbiturate melting point. The phenyl group attached adds to pi-pi stacking interactions and molecular weight, estimated at +5°C for its contribution. The ethyl groups have a smaller effect compared to aromatic or keto groups due to the flexibility and reduced ability to engage in favorable interactions, contributing a smaller increase, estimated at +1°C for each ethyl group.
Prediction: 190 (barbiturate base) + 10 (two keto groups) + 5 (phenyl group) + 2 (two ethyl groups) = 207°C

name: mephobarbital
source: Bergstrom C. A. S.; Norinder U.; Luthman K.; Artursson P. Molecular Descriptors Influencing Melting Point and Their Role in Classification of Solid Drugs. J. Chem. Inf. Comput. Sci.; (Article); 2003; 43(4); 1177-1408
Reason: The target compound mephobarbital contains several functional groups that influence its melting point. Starting with a simple barbiturate ring system, which has a reference melting point range of approximately 190 to 220°C, we will analyze the impact of various substituents. The barbiturate core structure forms via the condensation of urea and malonic acid and due to its highly conjugated and planar nature, typically exhibits a high melting point. This is due in part to strong intermolecular hydrogen bonding and dipole-dipole interactions. In the case of mephobarbital, modifications to the basic structure include: The presence of a phenyl ring (aromatic group), which generally increases the melting point due to π-π stacking and improved molecular rigidity. However, given that the phenyl ring is not directly involved in hydrogen bonding, its effect might be moderate, estimated at +10°C. The presence of two alkyl groups (ethyl groups) on the nitrogen atom of the barbiturate ring usually decreases the melting point due to an increase in molecular size, which can disrupt packing efficiency. Each ethyl group might reasonably be estimated to decrease the melting point by about -5 to -10°C. Overall, the decrease due to the alkyl substituents may offset or even outweigh the increase from the phenyl group. A tertiary amine function (N(C)) may also have both a steric and electronic effect, potentially decreasing the melting point (owing to the introduction of a bulky group and disruption of optimal packing) but also potentially participating in additional dipolar interactions. This can be considered roughly neutral to a slight decrease in the melting point and estimated at -5°C. Aggregating these considerations, the prediction for the melting point of mephobarbital is made.
Prediction: The reference barbiturate melting point range is 190-220°C. Phenyl ring: +10°C. Two ethyl groups: 2 * (-7.5°C). Tertiary amine function: -5°C. The estimated sum of modifications is 190°C (reference) + 10°C - 15°C - 5°C = 180°C.
